natural problem: Jason is trying to remember the five digit combination to his safe.  He knows that he only used digits 1 through 5 (possibly repeated), that every even digit was followed by an odd digit, and every odd digit was followed by an even digit.  How many possible combinations does Jason need to try?
natural solution: Of the digits 1 through 5, three are odd and two are even. If Jason's combination started with an odd digit, there would be 3 possibilities for the first digit. Since an even digit must follow, there would be 2 possibilities for the second digit.

Similarly, there would be 3 possibilities for the third digit, and so on. This would be a total of: $$3\times2\times3\times2\times3=108$$We can apply the same logic if Jason's combination started with an even digit.
There would be 2 possibilities for the first digit, 3 for the second digit, and so on, for a total of : $$2\times3\times2\times3\times2=72$$Overall, Jason must try $72+108=\boxed{180}$ combinations.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes combinations :: nat
assumes h0 : "combinations = card {s. length s = 5 \<and> (\<forall>i \<in> {0..3}. (s ! i mod 2 = 0 \<longrightarrow> s ! (i + 1) mod 2 = 1) \<and> (s ! i mod 2 = 1 \<longrightarrow> s ! (i + 1) mod 2 = 0)) \<and> (\<forall>d \<in> set s. 1 \<le> d \<and> d \<le> 5)}"
shows  "combinations = 180"

shows  "combinations = 180"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: How many 5-digit sequences are there such that the digits are between 1 and 5 inclusive, and each pair of consecutive digits has one even and one odd digit? The final answer is 180.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes combinations :: nat
assumes h0 : "combinations = card {c :: nat list. length c = 5 \<and> (\<forall> i < 4. (even (c ! i) \<longrightarrow> odd (c ! (i+1))) \<and> (odd (c ! i) \<longrightarrow> even (c ! (i+1)))) \<and> (\<forall> j < 5. c ! j \<ge> 1 \<and> c ! j \<le> 5)}"
shows  "combinations = 180"

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat and f :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat list"
assumes h0 : "n = 5"
and h1 : "set (f n) = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5}"
and h2 : "\<forall> xs \<in> f n. xs!0 = 1 \<or> xs!0 = 2 \<or> xs!0 = 3 \<or> xs!0 = 4 \<or> xs!0 = 5"
and h3 : "\<forall> xs \<in> f n. even (xs!0) \<longrightarrow> odd (xs!1)"
and h4 : "\<forall> xs \<in> f n. odd (xs!0) \<longrightarrow> even (xs!1)"
and h5 : "\<forall> xs \<in> f n. even (xs!1) \<longrightarrow> odd (xs!2)"
and h6 : "\<forall> xs \<in> f n. odd (xs!1) \<longrightarrow> even (xs!2)"
and h7 : "\<forall> xs \<in> f n. even (xs!2) \<longrightarrow> odd (xs!3)"
and h8 : "\<forall> xs \<in> f n. odd (xs!2) \<longrightarrow> even (xs!3)"
and h9 : "\<forall> xs \<in> f n. even (xs!3) \<longrightarrow> odd (xs!4)"
and h10 : "\<forall> xs \<in> f n. odd (xs!3) \<longrightarrow> even (xs!4)"
shows  "card (f n) = 180"

 There would be 2 possibilities for the first digit, 3 for the second digit, and so on, for a total of : $$2\times3\times2\times3\times2=72$$Overall, Jason must try $72+108=\boxed{180}$ combinations.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat and f :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat list"
assumes h0 : "n = 5"
and h1 : "set (f n) = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5}"
and h2 : "\<forall> xs \<in> f n. xs!0 = 1 \<or> xs!0 = 2 \<or> xs!0 = 3 \<or> xs!0 = 4 \<or> xs!0 = 5"
and h3 : "\<forall> xs \<in> f n. even (xs!0) \<longrightarrow> odd (xs!1)"
and h4 : "\<forall> xs \<in> f n. odd (xs!0) \<longrightarrow> even (xs!1)"
and h5 : "\<forall> xs \<in> f n. even (xs!1) \<longrightarrow> odd (xs!2)"
and h6 : "\<forall> xs \<in> f n. odd (xs!1) \<longrightarrow> even (xs!2)"
and h7 : "\<forall> xs \<in> f n. even (xs!2) \<longrightarrow> odd (xs!3)"
and h8 : "\<forall> xs \<in> f n. odd (xs!2) \<longrightarrow> even (xs!3)"
and h9 : "\<forall> xs \<in> f n. even (xs!3) \<longrightarrow> odd (xs!4)"
and h10 : "\<forall> xs \<in> f n. odd (xs!3) \<longrightarrow> even (xs!4)"
shows  "card (f n) = 180"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Consider a list of 5-element sequences, where each element in a sequence can be one of the numbers 1, 2, 3, 4, or 5. If the first element of the sequence is even, the second element must be odd; if the first element is odd, the second element must be even. This pattern continues for the rest of the sequence, with alternating even and odd elements. How many such sequences are possible? The final answer is 180.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat and count_combinations :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "n = 5"
and h1 : "\<forall>k. k \<ge> 1 \<and> k \<le> n \<longrightarrow> (even k \<longrightarrow> (\<exists>m. m = k + 1 \<and> odd m)) \<and> (odd k \<longrightarrow> (\<exists>m. m = k + 1 \<and> even m))"
and h2 : "count_combinations n = (\<Sum>i = 1..n. (i div 2) * (i div 2) * (i div 2) * (i div 2) * (i div 2))"
shows  "count_combinations 5 = 180"

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes combination :: "nat list"
assumes h0 : "length combination = 5"
and h1 : "\<forall> i. i < 4 \<longrightarrow> (combination ! i) \<in> {1..5}"
and h2 : "\<forall> i. i < 4 \<longrightarrow> (combination ! i) mod 2 = 1 \<longleftrightarrow> (combination ! (i + 1)) mod 2 = 0"
and h3 : "\<forall> i. i < 4 \<longrightarrow> (combination ! i) mod 2 = 0 \<longleftrightarrow> (combination ! (i + 1)) mod 2 = 1"
shows  "card {combination. \<forall> i. i < 4 \<and> (combination ! i) \<in> {1..5} \<and> (combination ! i) mod 2 = 1 \<longleftrightarrow> (combination ! (i + 1)) mod 2 = 0 \<and> (combination ! i) mod 2 = 0 \<longleftrightarrow> (combination ! (i + 1)) mod 2 = 1} = 180"

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes combinations :: "nat set"
assumes h0 : "combinations = {x | x. x \<in> {10000..99999} \<and> (\<forall>n \<in> {0..4}. even_digit_followed_by_odd_digit (digit x n) (digit x (n+1)))}"
and h1 : "\<forall> a b. even_digit_followed_by_odd_digit a b = ((a mod 2 = 0 \<longrightarrow> b mod 2 = 1) \<and> (a mod 2 = 1 \<longrightarrow> b mod 2 = 0))"
and h2 : "\<forall> x \<in> combinations. (\<forall> n. digit x n \<in> {1..5})"
shows  "card combinations = 180"

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat and f :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat list"
assumes h0 : "n = 5"
and h1 : "\<forall> x \<in> set (f n). x \<in> {1, 2, 3, 4, 5}"
